prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my sister’s boyfriend he’s not “family”?
My sister has been dating this guy for less than three months.  My personal feelings are that he’s an idiot.  I mean he’s young (either late teens or early twenties, idk) so it’s understandable.  I was an idiot back then too.  My problem with him is that he’s made some dangerous choices with my sister involved.  He wrecked his truck with her in it driving drunk.  He also took my sister around this ex felon that everyone in town knows is scary dude just so he could buy some “pot” if it was really pot.  The guy sells a lot more than pot.  He’s definitely not someone I want knowing or getting close with my sister.  

Despite that, it’s her choice who she dates so I’ve kept my opinions to myself until now.  I think he mistook politeness for friendship or something.  He’s shown up at my apartment to hang out.  When I visit my mom’s and he’s there he will basically attache himself to my hip.  Most annoying of all he started calling me brother and fam.  I know those aren’t always specifically referring to actual family, but it’s just what it’s felt like.  

It really got under my skin quickly.  The last time he did it I told him, “You’re not my family.  You’re the guy my sister is dating for now.”   He just said “alright” and I walked away. 

He’s just trying to be friendly and get close with his girlfriend’s family, I understand that.  It felt like it was time for a reality check on our relationship though.  I probably pissed my sister off in the process, I haven’t heard from her since it happened.  



"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. Let me start by reading through the situation carefully.

The author's sister has been dating a guy for less than three months. The author thinks the guy is an idiot and has made dangerous choices, like driving drunk with the sister in the car and hanging out with a known ex-felon to get drugs. The author is concerned about the guy's influence on the sister. The sister's boyfriend started calling the author "brother" and "fam," which made the author uncomfortable. So, the author told him directly that he's not family, just the guy the sister is dating. The sister hasn't talked to the author since.

Now, the question is whether the author was in the wrong. Let's break it down.

First, the author has valid concerns about the boyfriend's behavior. Driving drunk and associating with dangerous people are serious issues. The author is acting out of concern for the sister's safety. But the author is also the sibling, so maybe they should have approached this differently.

The author chose to confront the boyfriend directly, pointing out that he's not family. The boyfriend responded with "alright" and the author walked away. The sister isn't talking to the author now. 

Is the author wrong for being direct? Well, the boyfriend was trying to build a relationship with the family, maybe to feel more accepted. But if the author felt like the boyfriend was overstepping by calling him "brother" and "fam," especially given the short dating period and the red flags, maybe the author had a right to set boundaries.

On the other hand, the author could have talked to the sister first instead of confronting the boyfriend directly. That might have been a better approach to avoid hurting the sister's feelings. But the author might have felt that the sister was in danger and needed to be protected, even if the sister might be upset.

The key points here are consent and approach. The author's sister chose to date this guy, so the author shouldn't interfere too much. However, when the boyfriend starts interacting with the author in a way that feels intrusive (showing up uninvited, being overly familiar), the author has the right to set boundaries. The problem is how the author communicated it. Maybe a more respectful or private approach would have been better, but the author's intention was to protect the sister.

So, considering all that, I think the author isn't in the wrong because they were trying to protect their sister and set personal boundaries. However, the method could have been improved. The answer is B (No, the author is not in the wrong).
